misconceptions.name: Reads wrong quantity and type of inputs
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers as required, the program reads only 3 values and treats them as doubles representing velocities and time, which does not match the problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should read three double values v0, v1, and t from the user for this program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly 5 integer values from the user, because we are summing 5 integers.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Only three calls to nextDouble()
No use of integer input at all
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem requirements or reuse of code for a different physics problem instead of the requested sum-of-evens task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompt and input logic to read 5 integers (e.g., using nextInt()) and store/process them accordingly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly implements a physics acceleration input pattern (three doubles) rather than five integers; no attempt is made to read 5 values.

evidence.note: Prompt and input read three doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to process multiple values; it reads a fixed set of three values and performs a single calculation, so it cannot handle 5 separate integers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I only need to read a fixed small set of variables once and compute a single result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process 5 integers consistently, a loop (for or while) should iterate over the inputs, reading each integer and updating the running sum.
symptoms: No for or while loop in the program
Only direct sequential reads and a single calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to recognize that handling an arbitrary count of inputs typically requires a loop rather than hardcoding each input and calculation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for-loop that runs 5 times to read each integer and, inside the loop, update the sum as appropriate.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop construct in the program, and the logic is clearly built around a single calculation instead of repeated processing.

evidence.note: Main method uses only straight-line code without any loop to process multiple inputs.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether numbers are even (e.g., with n % 2 == 0); instead, it computes an average acceleration formula unrelated to even/odd checks.
misconceptions.student_belief: I do not need to distinguish between even and odd numbers for this program; I just compute a formula with the inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must check each input number with a condition like n % 2 == 0 to include only even numbers in the sum.
symptoms: No use of modulus operator (%)
No if-statement or boolean condition to test evenness
Logic is a physics formula instead of filtering numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Focus on a different problem (average acceleration) rather than implementing the required even-number filtering logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the input-processing loop, add an if (n % 2 == 0) condition to add only even numbers to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional or modulo operation anywhere in the code, and the implemented computation is unrelated to even checks.

evidence.snippet:
double averageAcceleration = (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeSeconds;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
evidence.note: Computation is an acceleration formula; there is no conditional or modulo even-number check.

misconceptions.name: Computes wrong quantity instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program computes an average acceleration and prints it, rather than accumulating and printing the sum of even numbers as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: The goal is to calculate and print the average acceleration from v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The goal is to maintain an integer accumulator that adds each even input and finally print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by that sum.
symptoms: No accumulator variable for sum
Output text refers to 'average acceleration' instead of sum of even numbers
Final value is result of a division formula, not a sum
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to be solving a different textbook problem about acceleration rather than the requested sum-of-even-numbers task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an integer sum variable initialized to 0, update it only when inputs are even, and at the end print 'Sum of even numbers: ' + sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Variable names, formula, and output message all clearly target average acceleration, not a sum of even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double averageAcceleration = (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeSeconds;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
evidence.note: Program computes and prints an average acceleration instead of summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Implemented Unrelated Program
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an unrelated problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the required task (summing even integers from five user inputs). Consequently, all core logical components of the assignment (looping 5 times, conditional filtering for even numbers, and using an accumulator) are missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either misunderstood the assignment requirements entirely or submitted the wrong file, leading to a program that solves an unrelated physics problem instead of the assigned numerical task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read five integers, use a loop, check each number for evenness using the modulus operator (`%`), and accumulate the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Class name does not match assignment purpose
Variable names and print statements relate to acceleration/velocity
Calculation uses subtraction and division instead of addition and modulus
Missing loop and conditional logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission of incorrect code or complete misunderstanding of the assignment scope.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the program from scratch based on the prompt requirements: start by defining variables for the accumulator and the loop structure.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted file 'AccelerationCalculator.java' calculates average acceleration, which is 100% contradictory to the prompt requiring a sum of even numbers program.

evidence.note: The class name indicates the program's focus is on acceleration, not finding the sum of even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double averageAcceleration = (finalVelocity - startingVelocity) / timeSeconds;

        System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
evidence.note: The core logic calculates average acceleration, ignoring the sum of even numbers requirement.

misconceptions.name: Used floating-point type for required integer input
misconceptions.description: The assignment required reading integer inputs. The student used `inputScanner.nextDouble()` and stored the results in `double` variables.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might not differentiate between `int` and `double` for general numeric input, or used template code meant for floating-point calculations.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem explicitly requires reading '5 integers', which should be handled using `int` data types and `inputScanner.nextInt().`
symptoms: Use of Scanner's `nextDouble` method
Variables defined as `double`
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of attention to data type specification in the prompt (and related to implementing the wrong problem that used doubles).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure variables are declared using the correct primitive type, matching the problem description (e.g., `int` for integers).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt requires integers, but the code explicitly uses `double` for startingVelocity, finalVelocity, and timeSeconds.

evidence.note: Input should have been read using `nextInt()` into `int` variables.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved - task mismatch
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have solved a completely different problem. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, the code reads 3 floating-point values and calculates acceleration.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believed they needed to solve an acceleration calculator problem, reading v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user and calculating the sum of only those that are even (divisible by 2 with no remainder).
symptoms: Code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration formula instead of even number sum
Prompt says 'Enter v0, v1, and t:' instead of 'Enter 5 integers:'
No loop to process 5 inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
Output is acceleration, not sum of evens
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for the wrong assignment or copied code from a different problem (likely a physics/acceleration problem).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) create a loop to read 5 integers, (2) check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulate only the even numbers into a sum, (4) print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submission solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation vs. sum of even numbers). The class name, variable names, calculation, and output all confirm this is not even an attempt at the assigned problem.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 double values and prompts for v0, v1, t (physics variables) instead of reading 5 integers for even number sum

evidence.snippet:

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + averageAcceleration);
evidence.note: Calculates acceleration using physics formula rather than summing even integers
